summary: Headcanon that Peter Parker watches MCU vine comps online and screams whenever his name shows up. He text all of the Avengers...
body: Headcanon that Peter Parker watches MCU vine comps online and screams whenever his name shows up. He text all of the Avengers links to the videos, which is met by confusion from most of them, especially Steve, who has no idea what Vine is. This prompts Peter, Harley, and Shuri to launch into wild explanations accompanied by a lot of screaming and hour-long comps.

summary: just a little *something* that i cooked up today ft. sick/sneezy peter lmaooooOOoOo “OK, so you see how this works?” Tony asked,...
body:
just a little *something* that i cooked up today ft. sick/sneezy peter lmaooooOOoOo

“OK, so you see how this works?” Tony asked, moving the hologram with a quick hand movement. Tony had been giving Peter a lesson in aerodynamics for the past hour and a half, mostly because Peter wanted to improve.

“Kind of,” Peter replied, sniffling and bringing a hand up to rub at his nose. “Hh’NNCH! Hahhh… huh’TISHH! TISSSH!”

He sniffed again, trying to ignore the urge to rub his nose. “Sorry, I always sneeze in threes.”

Tony dismissed the hologram and gave Peter a once-over. His hair was a little disheveled but he was also a teenage boy and probably didn’t spend too much time in the mirror. But Peter’s eyes looked glassy and his cheeks were tinged pink and—

Peter scrunched his nose when he rubbed it again before noticing Tony staring at him. “Is something wrong, Mr. Stark?”

“Maybe I should be asking you that question,” Tony said, turning off the computer. “Are you feeling OK?”

“Me? Oh, yeah. I’m feeling good,” he responded, rubbing the back of his head. “Why? Are you… are you feeling OK?”

“Do I need to make J.A.R.V.I.S. scan your vitals?”

“No, no. C’mon, Mr. Stark,” Peter said. “I need to improve for next time. Y’know, next time we get intruders from space or something?”

Tony groaned. “There’s not going to be a next time if you don’t take care of this. Health first. So what are we dealing with here?”

“Oh, I—” Peter gasped suddenly, bringing a hand to his face and pinching his nose shut. “Hehh…. H-hih! Hgk’NGKKT!” This was punctuated with a liquid sniffle before launching into two more. “H-hihh’NNGT! Hh’NNCH! Ugh, I’b sorry.”

“So, typical cold? What, you pick it up from school or something? God, kids.” Tony sighed. “Well, pack it up.”

“Where are we going?” Peter asked thickly, grabbing his backpack.

“Bed.”

⟵ 𝐩𝐫𝐞𝐯𝐢𝐨𝐮𝐬 | 𝐦𝐚𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐥𝐢𝐬𝐭 | 𝐧𝐞𝐱𝐭 ⟶

It’s February twelfth and New York City is very cold.

The sun has set, blanketing the city in a chill that hits you to your bones. Bria wishes she would’ve had the forethought to bring her coat. Instead, she holds her arms tightly to her torso, wishing the wind would let up. Bright yellow lights do nothing to warm the streets, nor do the throngs of people surging past her. She notices her shoes make much less sound compared to theirs, the crowds. She longs for home, but only for a second.

Once, twice she flicks the light switch, watching for the hanging bulb in the center of the kitchen to turn on. Once, twice it does not.

“Electric’s out again,” she calls. Her voice bounces off of damp wooden walls. Strange how something so spongy doesn’t absorb what she yells.

“I know,” a deep voice shouts back. “Quit reminding me.”

Bria sighs. She has quit reminding her, and for the past six months, it’s been a gamble as to whether the lights will work or not. It’s tiresome.

“Did you even pay it?”

“As if that’s any of your business. Aren’t you supposed to be in the garden?”

Bria shivers and clutches her sides. She’d rather be anywhere but there; the dirt is cold and hard-packed and weeds slither like snakes under her feet. It unsettles her more than sitting in the house does.

“No.”

Lies.

“I find that hard to believe. Get out there, make yourself useful.”

She bites her lip. “They have enough help out there. I’m too tired today.”

Heavy footsteps trod toward the kitchen and Bria finds herself staring at a very familiar and very tall figure.

“And I’m too tired to deal with this. Go.”

There’s no sense in arguing further, so she does, but she feels dirty all the way out the door.

And the second passes.

She ducks into what must be a pub; the music is trashy and loud and it smells like sweat, but it’s better than being out in the cold. There aren’t any seats, so she settles for leaning on the wall near the door.

People of all kinds (well, mostly brooding men) line the bar and wooden tables. Heavy accents fall from the lips of heavy-set bartenders and frothy mugs jut from calloused hands. Bria rubs hers together, struggling to find comfort in the space. It becomes even harder when a man sidles up next to her. His breath is laden with whiskey and slime when he speaks.

“You look lonely,” he comments, crossing his feet at the ankles. His position mimics hers as he leans up against the wall. Bria looks down at the floor, pretending to study the cracks in the oak.

“Not talkative, huh? That’s okay. I like ‘em quiet.”

Her head whips up, dark hair flying past her shoulders. Her brow pulls inward into a glare

“Excuse me?”

He laughs. He actually has the gall to laugh. It’s an ugly sound and it makes her stomach turn.

“Ah, so you do talk?” he says, scratching an unshaven cheek. “I was lyin’ before, see. I like ‘em vocal more than anything.”

The air seems to close in around her, becoming thicker and more like smog with every word he speaks. She takes her leave and ducks past him. Unfortunately, he follows.

“Aw, C’mon, I was just joking. Look, I’ll buy you a drink. How’s that?”

She doesn’t answer, just keeps on pushing through the crowd. Why is he still following? Isn’t he bored yet? God, New York is sleazy.

“Dollface, I’m talking to you., and you hear me. I know you do.”

His hand brushes just inches away from her arm and she recoils so sharply she nearly collides with a waitress. Met with a searing glare, the woman passing behind her gives her just a few seconds to scan for an exit. By a miracle, she finds one; a cherry-wood door, set into the left quadrant of a wall, beams at her. She makes for it but the footsteps don’t leave when the air becomes cold again.

“Don’t ignore me,” he demands. She quickens her pace along the sidewalk, wishing every second to find a crowd to disappear into. The yellow lights from before suddenly seem glaring, seem even colder than before. Bria clasps her hands together.

She doesn’t know how she’s evaded him so far, but she can tell he’s catching up. Even when she turns into an alley, he follows her past the garbage cans. He’s angry. Now she really wishes she would have brought her coat, and not just for the cold; in one of its pockets, she knows she keeps her keys. She longs to hold them in between her fingers as some kind of deterrent, some kind of defense.

She smells the liquor on his breath again when she stumbles, barely catching herself against the brick facade of a sandwich shop. Swift for a person his size, he pins her shoulder in place.

“Leave me alone,” she says shakily. Her words are met with a sneer, of all things. Maybe he means it to be charming rather than intimidating, but all it does is bring up a familiar coil in the pit of her stomach.

No, she begs herself. Not now. Not even now.

Her hands grow colder and colder as she leans in and she desperately tries to will away what coils around her fingers.

“Not even a smile for me?” he asks. “After all that trouble I went through for you.”

“Please…” Her voice is small, fragile. It shakes, but she’s not sure it’s with fear. He seems to enjoy it if anything. She presses harder against the wall as if she might disappear into it.

“Oh, don’t be like that. I said I’d buy you a drink, didn’t I? Isn’t that nice enough for you?”

His hand is so firm on her arm that it almost hurts. Her whole body aches, begging for the satisfaction, begging her to let go. Why won’t he just leave?

“I just.. I just wanna go home.”

A bold lie (for her, at least), but maybe it’ll work.

“How about I take you home?”

Nope. No dice.

Her teeth chatter before she clenches them tightly, holding her breath whenever he exhales against her face. It’s a dangerous dance of will versus nature; her hands are starting to hurt so badly that she can’t brush it off as the cold. She knows what it is no matter how much she wants to deny it.

“Huh? We’d have fun, I bet. We could have that drink there instead.”

“No. No, sir, please. Let me leave.”

“Without your number, at least? Not a chance.”

Bria glances frantically around, but no one looks back. Doesn’t anybody pay attention anymore? Or care? All it would take is a shout to distract him. To spare him.

He sighs and goes to grab her other arm.

“Look, I’m a nice guy,” he says, sliding his hand painstakingly slowly down past her elbow. Down to her hand.

No. Nope. Not a chance.

‘No,” she tries, “d-don’t touch me. Please don’t touch me.”

His face is so close to hers she wants to vomit. She can tell he’s looking at her mouth and her whole body almost lurches.

Anybody? Anybody? She cries out in her head as if someone might hear her. More protests die on her lips. He leans in to swallow them, and she panics.

The coiling in her stomach unravels when she screams, exploding in a burst of amber-yellow light. It chokes him like pollen, like stepping into a muggy, flower-filled field. Except this isn’t quite so pretty. The leering man is punted away by the force of it. His skin turns a sickly gray color. Whatever he wants to say is swallowed by the smog of energy taking his. Her energy. He falls to his knees.

And god, does she feel it flowing into her, feels the force of him. His organs pulse with untapped fuel, quickening and slowing in a delightful pattern. He’s choking on her, looking stricken and panicked as she was only a moment ago. And it feels good.

Good until she hears the screaming.

It’s not him, but it is the cries of nearly every other person wandering the avenue. Wide eyes find her first, watching her stand with her fingers curled around yellow light and her eyes so contrastingly dark. She releases his life so fast that she collapses onto her knees— it takes some of her own with it. She gasps for breath.

Scrambling to his feet, he spits at her. Bria can’t blame him, can’t even bring the energy to quip back, but she still curls inward.

‘Fuckin’ freak,” he hisses, but somehow still sounds petrified. “What in the fuck did you just do to me?”

Bria swears to god she sees his large brown boot rear back and aim for a kick. Her vision is going dark without a blow to the head; imagining what that would do to her right now makes her dizzy. But the blow never lands.

“Hey!” Someone shouts, a little high-pitched, but authoritative. Bria can’t see the man’s face this time, but he stumbles back so quickly he nearly falls on his ass.

“O-oh, holy shit.”

“What are you doing? Get out of here! You don’t kick someone when they’re down, asshole!”

She hears a very distinct thwip sound— a few in quick succession, in fact— before a lithe body thuds just a few feet before her. The leering man turns on his heel and runs away.

“And what are you all doing?!” The voice yells again. Bria, from her curled position on the cement, spots red feet turning away from her. She thinks they look like socks, but then… she’s barely awake, what does she know? She’s never heard so many people hurry away so quickly before, though.

It’s February twelfth and New York City is very cold.

The sun has set, blanketing the city in a chill that hits you to your bones. Bria wishes she would’ve had the forethought to bring her coat. Instead, she holds her arms tightly to her torso, wishing the wind would let up. Bright yellow lights do nothing to warm the streets, nor do the throngs of people surging past her. She notices her shoes make much less sound compared to theirs, the crowds. She longs for home, but only for a second.

[[MORE]]

Once, twice she flicks the light switch, watching for the hanging bulb in the center of the kitchen to turn on. Once, twice it does not.

“Electric’s out again,” she calls. Her voice bounces off of damp wooden walls. Strange how something so spongy doesn’t absorb what she yells.

“I know,” a deep voice shouts back. “Quit reminding me.”

Bria sighs. She has quit reminding her, and for the past six months, it’s been a gamble as to whether the lights will work or not. It’s tiresome.

“Did you even pay it?”

“As if that’s any of your business. Aren’t you supposed to be in the garden?”

Bria shivers and clutches her sides. She’d rather be anywhere but there; the dirt is cold and hard-packed and weeds slither like snakes under her feet. It unsettles her more than sitting in the house does.

“No.”

Lies.

“I find that hard to believe. Get out there, make yourself useful.”

She bites her lip. “They have enough help out there. I’m too tired today.”

Heavy footsteps trod toward the kitchen and Bria finds herself staring at a very familiar and very tall figure.

“And I’m too tired to deal with this. Go.”

There’s no sense in arguing further, so she does, but she feels dirty all the way out the door.

And the second passes.

She ducks into what must be a pub; the music is trashy and loud and it smells like sweat, but it’s better than being out in the cold. There aren’t any seats, so she settles for leaning on the wall near the door.

People of all kinds (well, mostly brooding men) line the bar and wooden tables. Heavy accents fall from the lips of heavy-set bartenders and frothy mugs jut from calloused hands. Bria rubs hers together, struggling to find comfort in the space. It becomes even harder when a man sidles up next to her. His breath is laden with whiskey and slime when he speaks.

“You look lonely,” he comments, crossing his feet at the ankles. His position mimics hers as he leans up against the wall. Bria looks down at the floor, pretending to study the cracks in the oak.

“Not talkative, huh? That’s okay. I like ‘em quiet.”

Her head whips up, dark hair flying past her shoulders. Her brow pulls inward into a glare

“Excuse me?”

He laughs. He actually has the gall to laugh. It’s an ugly sound and it makes her stomach turn.

“Ah, so you do talk?” he says, scratching an unshaven cheek. “I was lyin’ before, see. I like ‘em vocal more than anything.”

The air seems to close in around her, becoming thicker and more like smog with every word he speaks. She takes her leave and ducks past him. Unfortunately, he follows.

“Aw, C’mon, I was just joking. Look, I’ll buy you a drink. How’s that?”

She doesn’t answer, just keeps on pushing through the crowd. Why is he still following? Isn’t he bored yet? God, New York is sleazy.

“Dollface, I’m talking to you., and you hear me. I know you do.”

His hand brushes just inches away from her arm and she recoils so sharply she nearly collides with a waitress. Met with a searing glare, the woman passing behind her gives her just a few seconds to scan for an exit. By a miracle, she finds one; a cherry-wood door, set into the left quadrant of a wall, beams at her. She makes for it but the footsteps don’t leave when the air becomes cold again.

“Don’t ignore me,” he demands. She quickens her pace along the sidewalk, wishing every second to find a crowd to disappear into. The yellow lights from before suddenly seem glaring, seem even colder than before. Bria clasps her hands together.

She doesn’t know how she’s evaded him so far, but she can tell he’s catching up. Even when she turns into an alley, he follows her past the garbage cans. He’s angry. Now she really wishes she would have brought her coat, and not just for the cold; in one of its pockets, she knows she keeps her keys. She longs to hold them in between her fingers as some kind of deterrent, some kind of defense.

She smells the liquor on his breath again when she stumbles, barely catching herself against the brick facade of a sandwich shop. Swift for a person his size, he pins her shoulder in place.

“Leave me alone,” she says shakily. Her words are met with a sneer, of all things. Maybe he means it to be charming rather than intimidating, but all it does is bring up a familiar coil in the pit of her stomach.

No, she begs herself. Not now. Not even now.

Her hands grow colder and colder as she leans in and she desperately tries to will away what coils around her fingers.

“Not even a smile for me?” he asks. “After all that trouble I went through for you.”

“Please…” Her voice is small, fragile. It shakes, but she’s not sure it’s with fear. He seems to enjoy it if anything. She presses harder against the wall as if she might disappear into it.

“Oh, don’t be like that. I said I’d buy you a drink, didn’t I? Isn’t that nice enough for you?”

His hand is so firm on her arm that it almost hurts. Her whole body aches, begging for the satisfaction, begging her to let go. Why won’t he just leave?

“I just.. I just wanna go home.”

A bold lie (for her, at least), but maybe it’ll work.

“How about I take you home?”

Nope. No dice.

Her teeth chatter before she clenches them tightly, holding her breath whenever he exhales against her face. It’s a dangerous dance of will versus nature; her hands are starting to hurt so badly that she can’t brush it off as the cold. She knows what it is no matter how much she wants to deny it.

“Huh? We’d have fun, I bet. We could have that drink there instead.”

“No. No, sir, please. Let me leave.”

“Without your number, at least? Not a chance.”

Bria glances frantically around, but no one looks back. Doesn’t anybody pay attention anymore? Or care? All it would take is a shout to distract him. To spare him.

He sighs and goes to grab her other arm.

“Look, I’m a nice guy,” he says, sliding his hand painstakingly slowly down past her elbow. Down to her hand.

No. Nope. Not a chance.

‘No,” she tries, “d-don’t touch me. Please don’t touch me.”

His face is so close to hers she wants to vomit. She can tell he’s looking at her mouth and her whole body almost lurches.

Anybody? Anybody? She cries out in her head as if someone might hear her. More protests die on her lips. He leans in to swallow them, and she panics.

The coiling in her stomach unravels when she screams, exploding in a burst of amber-yellow light. It chokes him like pollen, like stepping into a muggy, flower-filled field. Except this isn’t quite so pretty. The leering man is punted away by the force of it. His skin turns a sickly gray color. Whatever he wants to say is swallowed by the smog of energy taking his. Her energy. He falls to his knees.

And god, does she feel it flowing into her, feels the force of him. His organs pulse with untapped fuel, quickening and slowing in a delightful pattern. He’s choking on her, looking stricken and panicked as she was only a moment ago. And it feels good.

Good until she hears the screaming.

It’s not him, but it is the cries of nearly every other person wandering the avenue. Wide eyes find her first, watching her stand with her fingers curled around yellow light and her eyes so contrastingly dark. She releases his life so fast that she collapses onto her knees— it takes some of her own with it. She gasps for breath.

Scrambling to his feet, he spits at her. Bria can’t blame him, can’t even bring the energy to quip back, but she still curls inward.

‘Fuckin’ freak,” he hisses, but somehow still sounds petrified. “What in the fuck did you just do to me?”

Bria swears to god she sees his large brown boot rear back and aim for a kick. Her vision is going dark without a blow to the head; imagining what that would do to her right now makes her dizzy. But the blow never lands.

“Hey!” Someone shouts, a little high-pitched, but authoritative. Bria can’t see the man’s face this time, but he stumbles back so quickly he nearly falls on his ass.

“O-oh, holy shit.”

“What are you doing? Get out of here! You don’t kick someone when they’re down, asshole!”

She hears a very distinct thwip sound— a few in quick succession, in fact— before a lithe body thuds just a few feet before her. The leering man turns on his heel and runs away.

“And what are you all doing?!” The voice yells again. Bria, from her curled position on the cement, spots red feet turning away from her. She thinks they look like socks, but then… she’s barely awake, what does she know? She’s never heard so many people hurry away so quickly before, though.

The red-footed figure crouches before her next, placing a gentle hand on her arm.

I wish you were afraid.

Panic surges in her chest. Without energy, though, it dies as quickly as it came. Her breathing comes in shallow pants and is muffled by her arms around her face.

“Okay, okay, uh… Oh, god, you can’t stay out here, can you? Of course, you can’t. Um…”

If not for the aching pressure on her chest, Bria might’ve laughed. She also might’ve shoved his hand off of her.

It takes him a moment to regain sense. He leans in close, craning his neck to catch her eyes. Her vision spots, barely catching his features. In fact, all she sees is white where his eyes should be and the same red skin of his feet.

Hallucinations. Holy shit. Need to get better at this part.

He starts talking to himself, running a hand (which is also red. What the hell is this guy?) over his face.

“Where do I even… Home? No, god, May would freak.. Wait.”

Whatever his face is made of, Bria sees it brighten even through her spotty vision. She’s curious but too spent to question him.

“Hey, I’m gonna take you somewhere safe, okay? Can I move you? Is that okay?”

She nods. Something about his tone manages to assure her. Maybe it’s the fact that he’s giving her a choice, which is mildly ridiculous. What other option does she have? It’s not as if she’s in a position to argue refuge.

Noting her meek nod, he wraps an arm around her back. She feels herself being lifted off the ground and against something solid and warm. The sensation almost makes her pass out.

Her teeth chatter before she clenches them tightly, holding her breath whenever he exhales against her face. It’s a dangerous dance of will versus nature; her hands are starting to hurt so badly that she can’t brush it off as the cold. She knows what it is no matter how much she wants to deny it.

“Huh? We’d have fun, I bet. We could have that drink there instead.”

“No. No, sir, please. Let me leave.”

“Without your number, at least? Not a chance.”

Bria glances frantically around, but no one looks back. Doesn’t anybody pay attention anymore? Or care? All it would take is a shout to distract him. To spare him.

He sighs and goes to grab her other arm.

“Look, I’m a nice guy,” he says, sliding his hand painstakingly slowly down past her elbow. Down to her hand.

No. Nope. Not a chance.

‘No,” she tries, “d-don’t touch me. Please don’t touch me.”

His face is so close to hers she wants to vomit. She can tell he’s looking at her mouth and her whole body almost lurches.

Anybody? Anybody? She cries out in her head as if someone might hear her. More protests die on her lips. He leans in to swallow them, and she panics.

The coiling in her stomach unravels when she screams, exploding in a burst of amber-yellow light. It chokes him like pollen, like stepping into a muggy, flower-filled field. Except this isn’t quite so pretty. The leering man is punted away by the force of it. His skin turns a sickly gray color. Whatever he wants to say is swallowed by the smog of energy taking his. Her energy. He falls to his knees.

And god, does she feel it flowing into her, feels the force of him. His organs pulse with untapped fuel, quickening and slowing in a delightful pattern. He’s choking on her, looking stricken and panicked as she was only a moment ago. And it feels good.

Good until she hears the screaming.

It’s not him, but it is the cries of nearly every other person wandering the avenue. Wide eyes find her first, watching her stand with her fingers curled around yellow light and her eyes so contrastingly dark. She releases his life so fast that she collapses onto her knees— it takes some of her own with it. She gasps for breath.

Scrambling to his feet, he spits at her. Bria can’t blame him, can’t even bring the energy to quip back, but she still curls inward.

‘Fuckin’ freak,” he hisses, but somehow still sounds petrified. “What in the fuck did you just do to me?”

Bria swears to god she sees his large brown boot rear back and aim for a kick. Her vision is going dark without a blow to the head; imagining what that would do to her right now makes her dizzy. But the blow never lands.

“Hey!” Someone shouts, a little high-pitched, but authoritative. Bria can’t see the man’s face this time, but he stumbles back so quickly he nearly falls on his ass.

“O-oh, holy shit.”

“What are you doing? Get out of here! You don’t kick someone when they’re down, asshole!”

She hears a very distinct thwip sound— a few in quick succession, in fact— before a lithe body thuds just a few feet before her. The leering man turns on his heel and runs away.

“And what are you all doing?!” The voice yells again. Bria, from her curled position on the cement, spots red feet turning away from her. She thinks they look like socks, but then… she’s barely awake, what does she know? She’s never heard so many people hurry away so quickly before, though.

The red-footed figure crouches before her next, placing a gentle hand on her arm.

I wish you were afraid.

Panic surges in her chest. Without energy, though, it dies as quickly as it came. Her breathing comes in shallow pants and is muffled by her arms around her face.

“Are you okay?” The figure asks, ever-so-gentle. Too gentle for someone like her.

She can’t answer; every time she opens her mouth, it closes again. He doesn’t press for an answer, so maybe he gets it. It’s a miracle he’s not yelling at her, too. There’s no way he didn’t see… that. But suddenly he’s panicked, too.

“Okay, okay, uh… Oh, god, you can’t stay out here, can you? Of course, you can’t. Um…”

If not for the aching pressure on her chest, Bria might’ve laughed. She also might’ve shoved his hand off of her.

It takes him a moment to regain sense. He leans in close, craning his neck to catch her eyes. Her vision spots, barely catching his features. In fact, all she sees is white where his eyes should be and the same red skin of his feet.

Hallucinations. Holy shit. Need to get better at this part.

He starts talking to himself, running a hand (which is also red. What the hell is this guy?) over his face.

“Where do I even… Home? No, god, May would freak.. Wait.”

Whatever his face is made of, Bria sees it brighten even through her spotty vision. She’s curious but too spent to question him.

“Hey, I’m gonna take you somewhere safe, okay? Can I move you? Is that okay?”

She nods. Something about his tone manages to assure her. Maybe it’s the fact that he’s giving her a choice, which is mildly ridiculous. What other option does she have? It’s not as if she’s in a position to argue refuge.

Noting her meek nod, he wraps an arm around her back. She feels herself being lifted off the ground and against something solid and warm. The sensation almost makes her pass out.

“Please don’t throw up on me,” is the last thing he says. After that, a sharp pull at her navel tells her they’ve been lifted into the air. With that, she does pass out.

⟵ 𝐩𝐫𝐞𝐯𝐢𝐨𝐮𝐬 | 𝐦𝐚𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐥𝐢𝐬𝐭 | 𝐧𝐞𝐱𝐭 ⟶

It’s February twelfth and New York City is very cold.

The sun has set, blanketing the city in a chill that hits you to your bones. Bria wishes she would’ve had the forethought to bring her coat. Instead, she holds her arms tightly to her torso, wishing the wind would let up. Bright yellow lights do nothing to warm the streets, nor do the throngs of people surging past her. She notices her shoes make much less sound compared to theirs, the crowds. She longs for home, but only for a second.

Once, twice she flicks the light switch, watching for the hanging bulb in the center of the kitchen to turn on. Once, twice it does not.

“Electric’s out again,” she calls. Her voice bounces off of damp wooden walls. Strange how something so spongy doesn’t absorb what she yells.

“I know,” a deep voice shouts back. “Quit reminding me.”

Bria sighs. She has quit reminding her, and for the past six months, it’s been a gamble as to whether the lights will work or not. It’s tiresome.

“Did you even pay it?”

“As if that’s any of your business. Aren’t you supposed to be in the garden?”

Bria shivers and clutches her sides. She’d rather be anywhere but there; the dirt is cold and hard-packed and weeds slither like snakes under her feet. It unsettles her more than sitting in the house does.

“No.”

Lies.

“I find that hard to believe. Get out there, make yourself useful.”

She bites her lip. “They have enough help out there. I’m too tired today.”

Heavy footsteps trod toward the kitchen and Bria finds herself staring at a very familiar and very tall figure.

“And I’m too tired to deal with this. Go.”

There’s no sense in arguing further, so she does, but she feels dirty all the way out the door.

And the second passes.

She ducks into what must be a pub; the music is trashy and loud and it smells like sweat, but it’s better than being out in the cold. There aren’t any seats, so she settles for leaning on the wall near the door.

People of all kinds (well, mostly brooding men) line the bar and wooden tables. Heavy accents fall from the lips of heavy-set bartenders and frothy mugs jut from calloused hands. Bria rubs hers together, struggling to find comfort in the space. It becomes even harder when a man sidles up next to her. His breath is laden with whiskey and slime when he speaks.

“You look lonely,” he comments, crossing his feet at the ankles. His position mimics hers as he leans up against the wall. Bria looks down at the floor, pretending to study the cracks in the oak.

“Not talkative, huh? That’s okay. I like ‘em quiet.”

Her head whips up, dark hair flying past her shoulders. Her brow pulls inward into a glare

“Excuse me?”

He laughs. He actually has the gall to laugh. It’s an ugly sound and it makes her stomach turn.

“Ah, so you do talk?” he says, scratching an unshaven cheek. “I was lyin’ before, see. I like ‘em vocal more than anything.”

The air seems to close in around her, becoming thicker and more like smog with every word he speaks. She takes her leave and ducks past him. Unfortunately, he follows.

“Aw, C’mon, I was just joking. Look, I’ll buy you a drink. How’s that?”

She doesn’t answer, just keeps on pushing through the crowd. Why is he still following? Isn’t he bored yet? God, New York is sleazy.

“Dollface, I’m talking to you., and you hear me. I know you do.”

His hand brushes just inches away from her arm and she recoils so sharply she nearly collides with a waitress. Met with a searing glare, the woman passing behind her gives her just a few seconds to scan for an exit. By a miracle, she finds one; a cherry-wood door, set into the left quadrant of a wall, beams at her. She makes for it but the footsteps don’t leave when the air becomes cold again.

“Don’t ignore me,” he demands. She quickens her pace along the sidewalk, wishing every second to find a crowd to disappear into. The yellow lights from before suddenly seem glaring, seem even colder than before. Bria clasps her hands together.

She doesn’t know how she’s evaded him so far, but she can tell he’s catching up. Even when she turns into an alley, he follows her past the garbage cans. He’s angry. Now she really wishes she would have brought her coat, and not just for the cold; in one of its pockets, she knows she keeps her keys. She longs to hold them in between her fingers as some kind of deterrent, some kind of defense.

She smells the liquor on his breath again when she stumbles, barely catching herself against the brick facade of a sandwich shop. Swift for a person his size, he pins her shoulder in place.

“Leave me alone,” she says shakily. Her words are met with a sneer, of all things. Maybe he means it to be charming rather than intimidating, but all it does is bring up a familiar coil in the pit of her stomach.

No, she begs herself. Not now. Not even now.

Her hands grow colder and colder as she leans in and she desperately tries to will away what coils around her fingers.

“Not even a smile for me?” he asks. “After all that trouble I went through for you.”

“Please…” Her voice is small, fragile. It shakes, but she’s not sure it’s with fear. He seems to enjoy it if anything. She presses harder against the wall as if she might disappear into it.

“Oh, don’t be like that. I said I’d buy you a drink, didn’t I? Isn’t that nice enough for you?”

His hand is so firm on her arm that it almost hurts. Her whole body aches, begging for the satisfaction, begging her to let go. Why won’t he just leave?

“I just.. I just wanna go home.”

A bold lie (for her, at least), but maybe it’ll work.

“How about I take you home?”

Nope. No dice.

Her teeth chatter before she clenches them tightly, holding her breath whenever he exhales against her face. It’s a dangerous dance of will versus nature; her hands are starting to hurt so badly that she can’t brush it off as the cold. She knows what it is no matter how much she wants to deny it.

He sighs and goes to grab her other arm.

summary: Hi again! I'm the same anon that asked about that AI theory and I agree with what you said, i don't know if they'll go down that...
question: Hi again! I'm the same anon that asked about that AI theory and I agree with what you said, i don't know if they'll go down that route or not tbh i dont really know what to expect of marvel at this point, but what do you think would be a good way for peter to have some closure, i guess you can say, about tony, since i highly highly highly doubt they're gonna bring him back. Hope i'm not annoying you with these questions!!
answer:
Definitely not annoying me!

Yeah, they definitely aren’t bringing him back. We can make all the fuss we want, Tony’s dead in the MCU. It sucks, but there’s no way they’re going to go back on THE shock ending 10 years in the making.

I think the thing I would really like to see as giving Peter closure, and thus really allowing him to start grieving properly, is Tony leaving a video telling him like “I did all of this for you because I love you. But that doesn’t mean this is your fault, and I chose this, and don’t let guilt eat you up.” As well as like… superhero advice, Avengers info and who to contact if he’s in over his head.

I don’t know, I feel like the only way Peter could really move on is if Tony, somehow from beyond the grave, tells Peter that the world may think they need the next Iron Man, but they really need Spider-Man. The kid who looks after the little guy.

question: how cool is the sanctum? Are you friends with the sorcerers? Do you have your own room? (I sound so creepy but ya know SKSKSKS XD)
answer:
Peter loves the Sanctum! 

(I made the mistake of coloring the first one and then continuing to do that so that’s why it’s taken so long. Also I got my tablet pen back!!!)
